question: Take a pew, Jack. You look well. What's it been, two years since we broke bread?
What a memory you've got. Maths always was your strong suit. What happened to the moaning Lisa?
answer: She went back to South Africa.

question: Did she? You were pretty thick at one time.
Hi-ya... I'll call you back. Now then...
All right. As what?
answer: I was thinking perhaps I could be a reader. You employ readers, don't you?

question: We do. For unsolicited manuscripts. We pay twenty pounds a manuscript. You might get two, maybe three in a week. Can you live on sixty pounds? Sorry. This is a no-smoking office, Jack. You've written a book, haven't you? I didn't read it myself, but -- Give me ten minutes, Fiona. Fiona used to read for me. Let me tell you about our operation. We like personality authors. People the public recognises. Celebrity's what sells books. We can always find someone to do the writing. First, we need the face. Then the concept. Right now I'm looking for a soccer novel. Something where a tycoon buys a lousy team and takes it to the top. Seven figure transfer fees. Corruption all down the line. Violence on and off the pitch. Steroids. Got any concepts? It could be a thug story. I tell you what. Why don't you think about it. A couple of pages. The pitch. Steroids. Got any concepts? It could be a thug story. I tell you what. Why don't you think about it. A couple of pages. With plenty of sex, of course.
answer: Interesting, Giles. I will think about it.

question: David Reynolds, I'm the Manager here. Sit down, John.
You've been recommended by the management here. They know your father. He has a bit of a reputation, hasn't he?
In any case, I understand you've had some previous experience... in South Africa. You'll find the rules a little different here. Before we start, you haven't got a police record, have you?
Where did you go to school?
I don't think I know that one. Private, I suppose. There are three types of casino in the U.K. High volume. Small faction. And MOTR. That's middle of the road. Us.
answer: Do you have a Salon Prive?

question: We tried. But there wasn't enough business. The punters like company. Let's see you handle the chips.
answer: I have to assume the serial numbers on the bowl and cylinder correspond.

question: We check every four days.
answer: Why four? And not three or five?

question: It's the procedure here. Now sort the chips.
Any exceptions?
Give me 365. Very good. Now take these colours... I want 780, but I want 500 in denominations of 25. Very good.
answer: You use two alternating, don't you?

question: We do.
They've been tested.
Could you stop that for a minute?
answer: I'm sorry, sir, I've called no more bets. 23 Red. Odd.

question: Haven't you forgotten something?
Wipe your hands. Not with your own cloth. Besides, your pockets will be stitched.
answer: What happens if I want to sneeze?

question: You won't. Not without permission. Fine. Now let's move on. How many aces are left?
I make it six.
What makes you so sure?
answer: It's a rule. Always stand by your first count. The odds are you're right.

question: Good call.
Let me just run through a few things. As a dealer you never gamble, not anywhere. We'll need your picture.
For the database. It can be accessed by every casino in the country. We have the same system for punters.
Ever?
Next point. Friendships between croupiers inside or outside the casino are discouraged. Relationships with females working here are expressly forbidden.
answer: We had the same rule at Sun City, but it was impossible to check.

question: This isn't South Africa. We'd know, because someone would report it. Believe me, someone always does.
answer: Does know? Or does report? What would happen if I knew something like that and didn't report it?

question: We'd know. There are no secrets in this casino. You'd be punished.
First offence Girlfriend?
She's not in the gaming business is she?
This is our Crow's Nest. I'm showing it to you now, but you'll never see it again.

We have tapes in here that go back six months. Let me show you something. See that? That was six weeks ago. The dealer missed it. The guy up here missed it, but I watch these tapes after hours. Nothing gets by me. Now the lady's in jail. It's easier to take ten million pounds from a bank than take one penny from this casino. You can start Monday week.
That hair will have to go.
This ain't exactly what you'd call mint.
How about five hundred.
How about we split the diff... Seven-fifty.
answer: Is that your idea of arithmetic?

question: I'm not a mathematician. I'm in business.
I couldn't resist them.
answer: You mean I won't resist them.

question: No, no. I'm not ready for you. There's some vodka in the freezer.
You really are a beautiful woman.
answer: It's not just inner beauty, is it?

question: Turn around. You're all I desire.
I. sold the car.
answer: You shouldn't have done that. I know what it meant to you.

question: I owe you for the rent. It's only a car. I can get another.
answer: Take it back. Till you sell your book.

question: Come on, Marion. Let's face the truth. Nobody's going to publish it.
answer: Of course they will. You just have to be patient. I'm betting on you.

question: I'm not much of a bet.
answer: You are to me. Come into my world. You're my prisoner.

question: I've got something to tell you.
I've got a job.
In a casino. As a croupier. A dealer.
It came my way. 450 a week.
answer: 450? What did you do, just walked in and said I want to be a croupier? Don't you need training?

question: I had training. In the Republic.
answer: You were a croupier there? You never told me that. I thought you just knew some gamblers.

question: I start Monday week.
answer: 450 a week. I've never earned that in my life. You're an enigma, you are. A fucking enigma.

question: I'm an undertaker. My office is in Shanghai. I'm an arms dealer.
Jack Manfred.
answer: Hi, Jack. Welcome to the cesspit.

question: Is it that bad?
Where do you live, Jack?
Have you got transport? I'm going over the river. I'll give you a lift if you like.
So how do you feel, your first night? I'll bet you're on a high.
She's my baby.
answer: How long have you worked at the casino?

question: Coming up to two years now. But I was away for six months.
Not bad. I have other interests, of course. I'm off to a little watering hole. Why don't you join me? Relax.
answer: No thanks, Matt. I need my eight hours.

question: I'll lay you five to one you won't sleep. In this job you have to unwind. Otherwise it'll kill you. I mean that.
What's the time?
How did it go?
You're shaking. What is it?
Poor baby. This'll relax you. I loved it blond.
answer: It's only hair. I haven't changed.

question: When you get home, I'm asleep. When I leave home, you're asleep.
answer: I'll see you in my dreams.

question: I'm sorry, sir, that's a late bet.
answer: What are you talking about? It's 11, I've won. With this lady.

question: You've won with the two chips you placed earlier, but the third chip was a late bet.
I'm afraid that's not so, sir.
Look Matt, there's something I have to say to you. I saw you cheating.
answer: What the fuck are you talking about?

question: That Greek guy who won at the end. You paid him out in 25s not 20s.
answer: I don't cheat, Jack. You've got it wrong.

question: I'm not going to report it.
If I see you do it again, I'll report it.
answer: I don't get you. Even if it was true, which it isn't, what the fuck difference would it make to you?

question: Because if a supervisor knew I'd seen you and I hadn't reported it, I'd lose my job as well. And I can't afford that.
answer: So it's Mr Clean. Wise up, Jack, this whole business is bent. The casino is nothing but legal theft. And that's OK. It's the system. Half the punters who come in are using stolen money, drug money, they haven't earned it. We earn our money. I'm on your side, Jack. I don't need an enemy.

question: You're talking about complicity.
answer: I don't know what that means. I'm talking about not rocking the boat. OK, now let's unwind.

question: Hey, Andros! This is Jack.
Mostly people in the casino business. A few drug dealers.
Just girls. What are you drinking?
Good call. Help yourself.
That bitch? No. Hey Jack, join us.
Don't worry, I won't report you!
Where've you been? I've got to give evidence in court at nine.
answer: Don't play the cop with me, Marion.

question: Take that back! Fucking take that back. I'm not a cop any more.
answer: I take it back. You're not a cop any more. You're a store detective.

question: Are you drunk?
This fucking job's getting to you. You haven't written a fucking word since you started.
answer: Do you have to swear all the time?

question: Well, that's my poor upbringing. I didn't go to no private school. I haven't got no class. I want to live with a writer. Not a fucking croupier. I don't even know what the word means. Croupier.
What do I mean to you? I want to know. Tell me.
What are you doing here? You know the rules.
answer: What about a drink on the way home?

question: I don't finish till eight. Make it nine and you're on.
Thinking of going back?
You know what? I'd like to buy you a drink.
answer: It's against the rules. Dealers are forbidden to talk to punters.

question: That's stupid. What are the odds of you being seen with me?
To coincidence.
answer: There's a casino in this hotel.

question: I'm not much of a gambler really. I just like this bar.
answer: So why did you come to my casino?

question: I was at a loose end. A friend of a friend gave me a courtesy membership.
No, no. I come every couple of years. I always think I'm going to stay. I'm from Cape Town originally
answer: I was born in the Transkei, on the Wild Coast.

question: Near the casino.
Now there's a coincidence. My father used to gamble there.
I loved the atmosphere. But it destroyed my poor mother.
And the lies. Gamblers are born liars.
answer: And superstitious too. It's like witchcraft.

question: That's Africa. There's an African in all of us, isn't there?
answer: We all came from Africa, supposedly.

question: Do you believe in astrology?
answer: Absolutely not. But then, I'm a Gemini and Geminis don't believe in astrology.

question: You know, you don't strike me as a typical croupier. I'm not married. I wear it to keep the flies off. I must go. Let me pay for this.
Toss you for it.
Don't worry.
answer: Jack. Do you need a ride?

question: No. Thanks.
Maybe another time.
answer: I'll take you up on that.

question: Goodnight.
answer: You don't recognise me? You had me barred. You fucking little worm.

question: Wait a minute. You got yourself barred.
Now I'm going to kill you.
answer: Jack! Jack. Leave him! Come on! Let's go. We don't want the cops here.

question: He won't cheat again.
It's the tension.
answer: Excuse the mess. Careful. Don't tear anything. It's funny, isn't it? If that guy hadn't come up to you, you wouldn't be here now.

question: I hate cheats.
answer: All men are cheats. I spent two years on the game. I don't mind telling you that. But don't worry, I'm clean as a whistle. I only did S & M. No blow jobs. No screwing.

question: Why did you quit?
I can imagine.
answer: Can you? I'm happy being a dealer. At least the punters keep their hands to themselves.

question: You called the casino a cesspit.
answer: Well it is. But I know where I am. I've been watching you work. You're the best in the place. But you know that.

question: I despise the job.
answer: Ah, we all say that. But if we hate it, why do we do it?

question: What do you really want to do?
Look, now I'm pumping you. I'm sorry. It's none of my business. It's just that you're not like the others.
Now he's a real shit. Don't get friendly with him. I'm sure he's got his hand in the till. You know what he said to me once? "I want to fuck the whole world over. That's my mission." The shit!
I look like shit.
Rough life, Jack.
I'll tell you later.
Hello... Fine. I took the job. I tried to call you, dad, but they said your line was disconnected. I'm getting there. Goodbye dad.
Why not?
answer: I don't like it at all. You had a wonderful character before, the Gambler. He was so romantic.

question: He was a loser. This guy's a croupier. He can't lose. People have shat on him all his life. Now he's in control. He's a winner.
answer: Is that your idea of a winner? He doesn't give a shit about anyone. He uses people and --

question: -- It's because of the sex, isn't it? You don't like the sex in it.
answer: I don't give a fuck about the sex. Most men'll fuck a lamppost. He's just a miserable zombie. Is that the way you feel now? Is that what's happened to you?

question: Marion. It's a book.
answer: Oh really. Then why is he called Jake. Why don't you come clean and call him Jack. There's no hope in it.

question: It's the truth.
answer: Without hope there's no point to anything.

question: Now wait a minute. What's so hopeful about your job? Spending the day catching poor people stealing. You said yourself the organised gangs get away with it. At least in the casino everybody gets caught. Rich or poor, the odds are the same. It's all relative.
answer: Crap. It's not relative. It's unfair. Like your casino. It's designed unfair. And your croupier's a little shit because he goes along with it.

question: You're just like all those other dummies out there. Fourteen and a half million to one! Is that your idea of hope?
Leave it.
You fucking little shit! You shopped me.
Reynolds got a doctor in. They forced me to take a dope test. It was positive. As you knew.
answer: I don't know anything about it.

question: Your boyfriend fucked me, smoked my dope, then shopped me. What do you think of that? I can't get a job now. You bastard. You're no different from Matt. A pair of vicious little shits, that's what you are.
answer: Look Bella, I don't know anything about this. You should talk to Matt.

question: Jack! I thought it was you. It's the hair!
answer: I'm working on that soccer story.

question: Right. Look, I must get back to Habib.

My author. He's a Terrorist. He's written a kill-and-tell book. Take care. Jack, look, next weekend I'm having a house party. Here... It's near Oxford. Why don't you come? It'll just be social. No business. Bring a friend. I've plenty of room.
She's a dab hand With a racquet, your friend.
answer: South African women are very sporty.

question: I can see. How did she get that shiner?
answer: I found her in bed with someone.

question: Who was he?
What happened?
answer: Remember the guy who cheated at the table?

question: You don't like cheats, do you. Which side do you like?
That trick tonight, I don't think I've ever seen that before.
answer: It can only work with amateurs, A pro would have spotted it.

question: I didn't.
Goodnight. I'm in trouble.
I owe a lot of money.
answer: Was that why you did the two grand? I couldn't help you.

question: I know that. But you can now.
answer: I don't have any money. switches on the light. JANI is looking distressed.

question: Some people I know, they're planning to rob The Golden Lion.
They mean it.
My creditors. One night, around three in the morning, they'll come into the casino -
answer: Forget it, Jani. It'll never work.

question: The point is, they want a man inside.
answer: And I thought you were a bright woman.

question: Just listen. You don't have to do anything criminal.
You don't have to be criminal. A man will come up to your table and deliberately cheat. You'll see him, stop him, and the guy will make a big scene. There'll be chaos. And that's when it'll happen.
You won't be committing a crime. The man will cheat, you'll just be doing your job, that's all.
answer: And I thought you were only after my body.

question: I've come to know you. You're honest. I trust you.
answer: What'll you do when it all goes wrong?

question: It won't.
You keep the ten thousand pounds.

These people will pay you ten thousand before and ten thousand after. They want someone they can be sure of, an honest dealer. That's the point. Not all dealers are honest. Mr Reynolds will never suspect you.
I didn't know what else to do. You're my last chance. Next time it'll be my neck.
I want to go back to Cape Town, I want to start again, clean.
How much do you owe?
Did they tell you to sleep with me?
answer: I told you, all bets are off. I'm sorry.

question: What for?
answer: I have to take the car.

question: Good night?
And your lady?
answer: She had to leave early. She asked me to thank you.

question: A bit unexpected, wasn't it?
How's that football story corning along?
answer: You said it was going to be social, Giles. No business.

question: It's beautiful. Thank you.
answer: I hope it brings you luck.

question: It will. That girl, she works at the casino --
answer: -- I don't care about her. Of course, I was angry. But not with you. The book is yours not mine. I was wrong, what I said about it. I hurt you, didn't I?

question: You're entitled to your opinion.
answer: It's none of my business what you write. And your job, that's none of my business either. I love you. And I've done everything wrong.

question: I'll leave the casino soon. I promise.
Within a month. Believe me, I'm going to quit!
answer: Then you can dye your hair blond again.

question: Come in. It's not the Ritz this time. Is it yes?
Thank you.
answer: It doesn't seem fair. You're offering me ten grand in cash but you can't afford a decent place.

question: Well, life's not fair. We know that.
answer: It's all relative. I need the money too.

question: Do you?
The date's not set yet. I'll call you. One last thing
answer: That bruise has cleared up nicely.

question: Bruise? Oh, yes. It's better.
answer: I've still got mine. And your hand too.

question: I took the bandage off yesterday. Would you like a drink?
answer: No thank you. I don't think we should meet again.

question: Aren't you ever tempted to gamble?
I can just imagine, being around so much money all the time...
Really?
answer: Gambling's about not facing reality. Ignoring the odds.

question: A Christmas festive atmosphere. The casino interior is decorated with red and green balloons, silver and gold streamers, a large tree hung with 1000 chips. JACK is now at a roulette table. He sees a PUNTER's watch

Two men in raincoats, DETECTIVES, approach REYNOLDS and talk to him. REYNOLDS becomes nervous, looks around the casino. The table at the bar where the SUITS sat is empty. The PRIVATE green baize door slowly closes. The ball bounces into number 5. There are cheers of delight from the winners, 5 is heavily covered.
answer: Sir, I can't accept that bet.

question: How did you know I was here?
answer: I thought you wouldn't want to spend Christmas Day alone in here.

question: Did you go to the casino?
answer: Happy Christmas. Now...noodles or rice? I don't want a criminal for a boyfriend.

question: There was a message, wasn't there?
answer: It's probably easier for you to eat the rice.

question: Marion! What did you tell the police?
Then what?
answer: Give up being a croupier, Jack. Or I'll shop you. All you have to do is keep your word. It's that simple. Here...use a spoon.

question: Leave me alone, Marion.
All right. I don't want to lose you. I'll quit. I swear to you.
answer: Why did you take the money?

question: I hate public transport.
I want to buy a car.
answer: How can anyone be that naive?

question: How do you feel, Jack?
Take your time. Two weeks. Three if you need it. We'll pay you sick leave. I don't want to lose you. You're a good man. Here...

Chapter Thirteen... It's all numbers, the croupier thought. A spin of the wheel. A turn of a card. The time of your life. The date of your birth. The year of your death. In the Book of Numbers the Lord said Jack thought, this is it. The famous two in the morning knock at the door. It wad pay-back time. But he wasn't afraid. He hadn't spent one penny of the ten grand. He'd covered himself. He knew the odds.
What were the odds of being killed by a car... on New Year's Eve?
Marion had been visiting his mother...no, no, not his mother - her mother.
answer: She was visiting her mother. Her mother. Who are you?

question: She was visiting her mother. Her mother. Who are you?
Who...
Who did it? Tell me!
answer: We think it's a hit-and-run. A drunk driver, probably, But there is a possibility of a revenge killing.

question: We think it's a hit-and-run. A drunk driver, probably, But there is a possibility of a revenge killing.
As you know, she was a WPC with the Met. up until two years ago. She called me last week. She'd got wind of a planned robbery at your casino.
answer: What had that got to do with her death?

question: You didn't recognise the man who attacked you, did you?
You did?
answer: I know a cheat when I see one. The man was a cheat. Do you gamble?

question: Jacko! How're you doing? I heard about the raid. Pity they didn't pull it off. I wish I'd been there.
What? You know what happened to me, don't you? That bitch Bella shopped me. I'd like to beat the shit out of her.
answer: I'd like to buy you a drink.

question: You've been avoiding me.
I'm Lucy.
answer: And what do you do, Lucy?

question: I'm a witch. A white witch. Why don't we move on?
answer: Are you going to put a spell on me?

question: I might.
answer: Nice car. How much did you pay for it?

question: Too much. Eighteen hundred. Where to?
Hello...
Jani! Where are you?
answer: Sun City. I've been meaning to call you for months.

question: How are you?
answer: Great. I'm getting married. At least, I think I am.

question: Did you solve your problems?
answer: Yes. I'm all over that now. Jack, hold on a minute. There's someone here who wants to talk to you...
